subject: RE: [junit] What happened to getName()?

messageBody:
Chaz,

GetName() was removed in the move to a DSL-style interface with JUnit 4. The
tradeoff was that if we dropped getName(), programmers would be free to
subclass from anything for their test classes. I haven't subsequently used
this freedom to any good effect, but it seemed like a good idea at the time.

With 4.7 (available from GitHub or the 4.7 snapshot on SourceForge), you can
use interceptors to capture the test's name. It's easy, if you already know
about interceptors that is and you don't waste 15 minutes remembering that
interceptors have to be public and that you still have to run with the
Interceptors runner. They say that memory is the second thing to go...

@RunWith(Interceptors.class)
public class NameTest {
String name;
@Interceptor
public StatementInterceptor namer= new StatementInterceptor(){
@Override
public Statement intercept(Statement base, FrameworkMethod method) {
name= method.getName();
return base;
}
};
@Test
public void funnyName() {
assertEquals("funnyName", name);
}
}

This suffers from cleverness, but it doesn't get the problem solved without
an entire new runner, which was the point of interceptors in the first
place.

Regards,

Kent

Subject: [junit] What happened to getName()?





Hi,
I was wondering, is there a particularly good reason why the most useful
method getName() was removed in junit 4.x? Is there another method or way
for me to get the current name of the method executing for reporting
purposes?

Thanks,

chaz
